comment.author: 53769726@N04
comment._content: I actually owned one of those cars at one time. Most dependable car I ever owned and it was still going strong years after I sold it to a neighbor.

comment.author: 21628570@N03
comment._content: Wonderful old capture!! captures the beauty and innosence of the times, and makes me feel of how things would be now if we still had this!!!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Is the negative reversed?  I remember in 1967 when Sweden changed driving on the left as we do in Ireland and the UK and began driving on the right  (wrong) side of the road.  Google tells me that that was Dagen - H on 3rd September 1967??

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] The picture is not reversed. On a narrow Swedish country road like this, the car in the picture actually stands on the left side. The diversion from left-hand to right-hand traffic in Sweden took place on the 3rd of September, 1967. Read more about it on Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dagen_H /Anna B.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swedish_heritage_board] Thank you Anna for the response.  I was going on the position of the steering wheel which is on the left hand side of the car which was manufactured in Sweden in the 1940's and long before Dagen H.  I can read about it on Wikipedia but I am old enough to remember 1967 and read all about it at the time.

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ok, I see what you mean about the steering wheel! The Swedish article on Wikipedia about "H Day" tells that most Swedish cars were produced with the steering wheel on the left side even before 1967 (as they still are today). One reason was was that the Swedish authorities had indicated at an early stage that a diversion to right-hand traffic would come in the future. Another reason was that the cars mostly where exported to countries with right-hand traffic, where left-hand driven cars where stipulated. 
I'm indeed no expert on cars, but now I've learned more, thanks to you! :)

/Anna B.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swedish_heritage_board] Anna, I'm shocked!  A European country with forward thinking and planning???? It was wise of them to do so and of course dependable Swedish cars were always a big attraction in those days of very unreliable cars from many other countries.  As a boy growing up in the 40's and 50's car "spotting" was something we did and admired the new models on the market.  Spotting a Volvo or a Saab was a big deal as they were scarce but many of the models we saw then are still going today, a tribute to the work of your countrymen and women.
